awd_titl_txt: II-New: SC-CAN: South Carolina's Wireless Communication and Airborne Networking Collaboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, the investigators will configure air-to-ground networks with a small fleet of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) to conduct experiments with two goals: (1) explore several research themes in wireless communications and networking in order to improve the reliability and efficiency of future wireless systems, (2) enhance the learning experience of graduate/undergraduate students by allowing them to conduct hands-on course projects to concretize their understanding of various components of wireless communications and networking. A key component of these goals is the use of  UAVs, whose use is growing rapidly, for an ever-expanding variety of applications.  Outcomes of this project will benefit a variety of communities, e.g., public safety, commercial users, UAV manufacturers, etc. In addition, the project will train a group of students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels with insights on communication, antennas, and networks. Ultimately the students can become important members of the workforce in a variety of communities. Future collaborations with other university and local organizations who may use UAVs will also be explored.

This project, SC-CAN, provides the necessary impetus to research efforts at University of South Carolina at Columbia towards advancing the state of the art in various aspects of wireless communication and networking related to UAVs. This includes (1) enabling  research in developing new channel models for airborne networks in various environments and for providing highly dependable wireless services by detecting and localizing jamming attacks, (2) facilitating redesign of wireless protocols that utilize physical layer knowledge to improve spectrum usage and consequently increase network throughput significantly, (3)  analysis and enhancement of  the privacy and security of airborne networks, and (4) providing tools and evaluation platforms for research on designing reconfigurable antenna systems. This research will be made possible by the new laboratory equipment and UAVs, which will enable a great variety of experiments on a wide range of issues in UAV communications and networking.

por.por_cntn:
The SC-CAN project has significantly enhanced the laboratory facilities in the area of wireless communications and networking at the University of South Carolina, in two departments of the College of Engineering and Computing: Computer Science and Engineering, and Electrical Engineering. With new signal analysis capabilities and software-defined radios (SDRs), plus multiple small unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), we have laid the foundation for future research and education in this field at our university, beginning with the four faculty members involved in this project. Our primary outcomes are

  • Establishment of flight control for several small UAVs;
  • Development of multiple programs that enable us to employ SDRs to create communication links from UAVs to ground stations and to each other;
  • We have acquired necessary equipment to develop miniaturized frequency reconfigurable antenna and components for current and future UAV wireless communication applications.
  • We have discovered several hardware-related issues that can affect the integrity of the motion sensors (e.g., accelerometers). Such sensors are widely used on drones and robots and can affect correct actuation. We show that by injecting intentional acoustic interferences, we are able to modify the accelerometer readings, which could potentially cause incorrect control decision on drones or autonomous vehicles.
  • Utilizing the equipment of the SC-CAN project, we have discovered one of the causes of wireless channel wastage, i.e., collision as a result of backoff operation in CSMA networks.  By performing hierarchical backoff this wastage can be reduced significantly. We have demonstrated the feasibility and evaluated the benefits of hierarchical backoff. Our evaluations show that hierarchical backoff can offer gains of up to 25% over 802.11 and better fairness, particularly at high loads.
  • To assist collaborative channel exploration by multiple drones and ground robots, we have explored a way of constructing communication map indoors, which given an ordered pair of locations provides an estimate of the link quality. Our method measures signal strength at a limited a number of candidate locations and integrates these measurement into a Gaussian Process (GP) to model the communication map. We find that our proposed approach makes the robots consistently travel 30% less distance at a given time slice.

Work on this project has involved several graduate and undergraduate students. These students not only gained experience operating SDRs and UAVs, but also gained knowledge in the broad area of wireless networking. Their work in flight controls and SDR programming will be passed on to future students.
